metadata.title: Use of nano-α-Al2O3 to improve binary eutectic hydrated salt as phase change material

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/solmat
Use of nano-α-Al2O3 to improve binary eutectic hydrated salt as phase change material
Yushi Liua,b, Yingzi Yanga,b,⁎
a Key Lab of Structures Dynamic Behavior and Control (Harbin Institute of Technology), Ministry of Education, Harbin 150090, Heilongjiang, China b School of Civil Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150090, Heilongjiang, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano-α-Al2O3 Eutectic hydrated salt Supercooling Thermal conductivity Thermal energy storage
A B S T R A C T
In this paper, a novel Na2SO4·10H2O-Na2HPO4·12H2O eutectic hydrated salt (EHS) with melting temperature of 31.2 ℃/no phase separation was firstly prepared for thermal energy storage applications at heating solar greenhouses and active solar heating systems in buildings. In order to inhibit supercooling and enhance thermal conductivity of EHS, nano-α-Al2O3 at different weight proportions was loaded into EHS. The multi-factors orthogonal test method has been employed to evaluate the nucleation effects of nano-α-Al2O3. Besides, various characterization techniques such as DSC, OM, SEM and FT-IR were adopted to investigate the thermal properties, microstructure and chemical stability. The results showed that nano-α-Al2O3 was a highly effective nucleating agent and excellent thermal conductive filler. The supercooling degree was reduced from 7.8 ℃ to 1.6 ℃ and the thermal conductivities were improved by up to 61.3% when adding 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 and 1.0 wt% borax. Moreover, the latent heat of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS decreased by only about 8% and its melting point maintained constant as that of pure EHS. In addition, the modified EHS had good thermal and chemical stability after 200 thermal cycles.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The solid–liquid phase change material (PCM) used for thermal energy storage by absorbing and releasing heat energy during phase transition has become a hot research topic in recent years due to its high energy storage density, smaller volume change and relatively constant phase change temperature [1–4]. Most of the solid–liquid PCMs explored by researchers are organic, such as paraffin [5,6], nonparaffin [7,8], organic binary mixtures [9,10], etc. However, compared with organic PCMs, the inorganic PCMs like hydrated salts show advantages of larger transformation enthalpy, nonflammability, abundant sources, cost effective and so on [3,11,12], which have been showing extensive prospects for use in thermal energy storage.
Hydrated salts can be used as low-temperature heat storage materials at heating solar greenhouses and active solar heating systems in buildings, among which sodium sulfate decahydrate (Na2SO4· 10H2O) has received much attention because of its applicable phase change temperature (about 30 ℃), high latent heat and low cost [13– 15]. Unfortunately, the drawback of phase separation of Na2SO4· 10H2O limits its application in heat storage [16]. Among ordinary hydrated salts, disodium hydrogen phosphate dodecahydrate (Na2HPO4·12H2O) rarely has phase separation, but its phase change
temperature of around 40 ℃ is not compatible with the scope of application above. Nevertheless, the phase change temperatures of many PCMs can be adjusted by mixing with other PCM, and phase separation of a few hydrated salts can be controlled to some degree [17–19].
In addition, the supercooling and low thermal conductivity are the other two serious problems associated with all hydrated salts [20,21]. The supercooling can be avoided by adding suitable nucleating agents into hydrated salts [3,22]. For example, sodium tetraborate (borax) can remarkably reduce supercooling degree of Na2SO4·10H2O [23,24], whereas it does less effective work for reducing supercooling of Na2HPO4·12H2O. Therefore, for a multiple system of hydrated salts, the effect of compounded nucleating agents may be superior to a single nucleating agent. Based on heterogeneous nucleation theory, the nucleating agents suspending in hydrated salts system can serve as nucleation sites on which crystals are easier to nucleate and grow. The adsorption of ions and molecules on surfaces of solid particles is a critical step for crystal growth [27]. And when particle size reduces to a nanometer level, adsorption capacity will significantly increase [28]. Hence, the nanoparticles can be considered as proper nucleating agents to diminish supercooling degree of hydrated salts. In previous works, the nucleating agents proposed are virtually hydrated salts and
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.solmat.2016.09.050 Received 8 January 2016; Received in revised form 28 August 2016; Accepted 29 September 2016
⁎ Corresponding author at: Key Lab of Structures Dynamic Behavior and Control (Harbin Institute of Technology), Ministry of Education, Harbin 150090, Heilongjiang, China. E-mail address: yzyang@hit.edu.cn (Y. Yang).
Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells 160 (2017) 18–25
0927-0248/ © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
crossmark
inorganic salts [23–26], which make no contributions to the thermal conductivity. M. Hemmat Esfe et al. [29] studied the effects of nanoAl2O3 on thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol based Al2O3 nanofluids, revealing that the thermal conductivity increased dramatically with Al2O3 concentration increasing. Moreover, the same results of thermal conductivity improvement have occurred in the methanol based Al2O3 nanofluids and Al2O3-H2O nanofluids [30,31]. Therefore, the nanoparticles, such as nano-metallic oxide particles, may have a remarkable advantage of enhancing the thermal conductivity of inorganic hydrated salts.
In this work, a new Na2SO4·10H2O-Na2HPO4·12H2O eutectic hydrated salt (EHS) has been developed as PCM, which supplies a suitable application temperature without phase segregation. The nanoparticle-modified EHS was prepared by dispersing α-Al2O3 nanoparticles into EHS to inhibit the supercooling as well as improve thermal conductivity. And the effect of reducing supercooling degree by combining EHS with the compounded nucleating agents of nano-αAl2O3/borax was evaluated through the significance level of the statistics based on multi-factors orthogonal test. The thermal, crystallographic and morphological characterizations and thermal cycling stability of the nanoparticle-modified EHS were conducted as well.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Sodium sulfate decahydrate (Na2SO4·10H2O, AR, Tianjin Hengxing Chemical Preparalion Co., Ltd.) and disodium hydrogen phosphate dodecahydrate (Na2HPO4·12H2O, purity＞99%, Tianjin BENCHMARK Chemical Co., Ltd.) were employed as the PCMs. Borax (Na2B4O7· 10H2O, AR, Tianjin Zhiyuan Reagent Co., Ltd.) and nano-sized αalumina (nano-α-Al2O3), which was obtained from Shenzhen Jingcai Chemical Co., Ltd., with purity higher than 99.9% and an average size of 100 nm were selected as nucleating agents. Sodium alginate (SA, viscosity=1050–1150 m Pa s, Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute) and hydroxyethyl cellulose (HEC, viscosity=50000– 60000 m Pa s, Henan Datian Food Ingredients Co., Ltd.) used for the mixed surfactants (MS) were also purchased. All chemicals were directly used as received without any further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Preparation of Na2SO4·10H2O-Na2HPO4·12H2O eutectic hydrated salt (EHS)
sections.text:
The Na2SO4·10H2O-Na2HPO4·12H2O eutectic mixtures were prepared by replacing Na2HPO4·12H2O with 10, 20, 25 and 30 wt% Na2SO4·10H2O, respectively. Binary hydrated salt mixtures were filled into a small beaker, melting completely at 60 ℃ in water bath, and the solution under constant temperature was stirred for 5 min at 1000 rpm. Then, during the process of solidification, the real-time temperature of the hydrated salt mixtures was recorded by the multichannel temperature measuring system with an accuracy of ± 0.1 ℃.
2.2.2. Modification of EHS In order to obtain a high-performance modified EHS with lower supercooling degree and higher thermal conductivity, the amount of nano-α-Al2O3 and borax were investigated in terms of different mixed surfactants (MS) ratios (the mass ratio of MS to nano-α-Al2O3). MS is comprised of sodium alginate (SA) and hydroxyethyl cellulose (HEC) at the rate of 1:1 in mass. SA serves as an emulsifier to obtain more uniform solution, and HEC plays the role of stabilizer. What's more, SA as anionic surfactant and HEC as nonionic surfactant were mixed together to engender synergism effect of nonideal mixed system of surfactants, which would have a better performance in the highconcentration salt solution of EHS [32,33].
Orthogonal tests designed through Statistical Product and Service
Solutions software (SPSS) were carried out. The experiment was organized as an L8 (4
1×24) orthogonal array, as listed in Table 1. The supercooling degree was chosen to evaluate the influence of the three factors including nano-α-Al2O3, borax and MS ratio. Nano-α-Al2O3 was dispersed and stabilized by the mixed surfactants (MS) in accordance with the designed MS ratio.
Sample preparation was as follows: the Na2SO4·10H2O-Na2HPO4· 12H2O eutectic hydrate salt (EHS) was first melted at around 55 ℃ and then borax and SA were dissolved in molten EHS in order. Solution was stirred by magnetic stirrer at 1000 rpm at around 55℃for 2 h. Nano-αAl2O3 particles were added into the solution later and stirred at 1500 rpm for 1 h. Then, all the suspensions were ultrasonicated for 30 min at 120 W to obtain a good dispersion. Finally, HEC was added into suspension and mixed at 1500 rpm for another 2 h. The real-time temperature of solidification process of all the samples was recorded by the multichannel temperature measuring system.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization and testing
sections.text: Thermal properties of modified EHS were measured using a differential scanning calorimetry (NETZSCH, DSC 200F3). The scanning temperature range was from 15 ℃ to 55 ℃, and the scanning rate was 5 ℃/min. The thermal conductivities of modified EHS was tested by a thermal conductivity measuring apparatus (XI'AN XIATECH, TC3000) based on hot-wire method. The estimated uncertainty in the thermal conductivity measurement was ± 3%. The microstructure of EHS doped with nano-α-Al2O3 was examined with environmental scanning electron microscope (SEM, FEI Co., Quanta 200). The crystallography features of before and after modification were observed using the optical microscopy (OM, OLYMPUS, DSX500). FTIR spectrometer (TIANJIN GANGDONG SCI. & TECH., FTIR-650) was used to check functional groups, in which the scanning range was 400– 4000 cm−1. The thermal cycling tests were carried out in a thermocycling test chamber by heating and cooling the samples between 5 and 60 ℃ repeatedly.

sections.heading: 3.1. Determination of EHS
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows the cooling curves of pure Na2HPO4·12H2O and binary hydrated salt mixtures. It can be obtained from Fig. 1 that the phase change temperatures of binary hydrate salt mixtures with different Na2SO4·10H2O replacement percentage (0, 10, 20, 25 and 30 wt%) are 39.6, 34.3, 32.7, 31.2 and 32.3 ℃, respectively. With Na2SO4·10H2O replacement ratio increasing, the phase change temperature decreases firstly and then increases, and the lowest temperature reaches at 31.2 ℃ when the replacement ratio is 25 wt%. Therefore, the recipe of 25 wt% Na2SO4·10H2O-75 wt% Na2HPO4·12H2O eutectic hydrate salt (EHS) was determined.
The state of molten Na2SO4·10H2O, EHS and Na2HPO4·12H2O is displayed in Fig. 2. It can be observed that Na2SO4·10H2O has a severe phase separation since the anhydrous salt cannot be entirely dissolved in its solution at the melting point. In contrast, there is nearly no phase
separation in the solution of EHS. The phase change temperature and latent heat of the EHS were measured by DSC as shown in Fig. 3. Its phase change temperature is 31.2 ℃ which is very applicable to heating solar greenhouses and active solar heating systems in buildings. And its latent heat is 280.1 J/g, higher than that of most of low-temperature phase change materials, showing a prominent heat storage capacity. However, the Fig. 1(d) reveals that the supercooling degree of EHS is 7.8 ℃ which is too high for engineering application.
3.2. Modification of EHS
As shown in Table 1, the role of nano-α-Al2O3 in contributing to inhibiting supercooling of EHS and the necessity of borax as auxiliary nucleator have been discussed in details. Furthermore, the emphasis is focused on the investigation of MS ratio, because the addition of MS may impact the supercooling, and the MS ratio is associated with the dispersion of nano-α-Al2O3 in EHS solution, which may affect supercooling of EHS.
The experiment arrangements and results through orthogonal test are listed in Table 2. Fig. 4 shows cooling curves of N1–N8 samples. The supercooling degree is presented in Table 2 as the evaluation indicator.
In order to investigate the significance of the three factors and the trends in inhibiting supercooling of EHS for each based on the supercooling degree, the analysis of variance (ANOVA) and factor-level trend of orthogonal experiment were carried out using SPSS, and the results are shown in Table 3 and Fig. 5, respectively.
Table 3 indicates that the significance of the three factors under investigation with respect to supercooling is in the order: nano-αAl2O3 > borax >MS ratio. Since the P-value obtained for nano-α-Al2O3 is 0.002, which is clearly lower than 0.01, the effect of addition of nanoα-Al2O3 on supercooling degree is highly significant. The P-value of 0.025 for borax is greater than 0.01 and less than 0.05, possessing a great influence on supercooling of EHS. Remarkably, the P-value of 0.609 for MS ratio is far greater than 0.1, hence MS ratio has little influence on supercooling of EHS.
As presented in Fig. 5, the supercooling degree of EHS greatly decreases by nearly 6 ℃ as the additive amount of nano-α-Al2O3 reaches 3.0 wt%. The addition of 1.0 wt% borax has reduced the supercooling degree by about 1 ℃. However, the change of MS ratio makes the supercooling degree 0.1 ℃ larger or less, which is negligible. Considering the results shown in Table 3 and Fig. 5, nano-α-Al2O3 is
the main nucleating agent which is crucial for preventing from the supercooling of EHS. And borax plays an assistant role against the supercooling. Importantly, the MS ratio ranging from 2:3 to 1:1 (w/w) is appropriate, and the lower MS ratio of 2:3 is effective enough to be used in modification of EHS.
However, it is uncertain whether borax addition of 1.0 wt% or more is suitable for preventing supercooling of EHS. As for nano-α-Al2O3, the supercooling degree is decreased to the lowest when the content of nano-α-Al2O3 is 3.0 wt%, and it rebounds slightly when the addition of nano-α-Al2O3 increases to 4.5 wt% (Fig. 5). According to Duncan’s
multiple comparison of nano-α-Al2O3 based on supercooling degree (Table 4), it is obvious that there is no significant difference between 3.0 wt% and 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 (P-value=0.293 > 0.05) in inhibiting supercooling of EHS. Therefore, it would be better to explore the effect of nano-α-Al2O3 content above 4.5 wt% on supercooling of EHS. The further experiments are performed as shown in Table 5. The cooling curves of E1–E4 samples are showed in Fig. 6.
It can be seen from Table 5 that the supercooling degree is enlarged from 1.6 ℃ to 2.4 and 3.7 ℃ as the nano-α-Al2O3 content is increased from 4.5 wt% to 5.0 and 6.0 wt%. Moreover, compared with the 4.5 wt % nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS with 1.0 wt% borax (N8), the supercooling degree of samples elevates by 0.7 and 1.0 ℃, respectively, with borax content equal to 2.0 and 3.0 wt%. That is, a certain amount of nano-α-Al2O3 and borax, as presented in sample N6 and N8, is significantly effective to prevent supercooling of EHS, while the further increasing content of nano-α-Al2O3 and borax, as presented in sample E1-E4, plays an opposite role. Thus, 3.0 wt% and 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS with 1.0 wt% borax (N6 and N8), of which supercooling degree is 1.2 ℃ and 1.6 ℃, respectively, are studied in the following experiments.
Note:MS ratio of all the samples is 2:3 (w/w); N6 and N8:the modified EHS determined by the orthogonal experiment; E1– E4:the EHS with different content of nano-α-Al2O3 and borax.

sections.heading: 3.3. DSC analysis
sections.text:
The DSC melting curves of 3.0 wt% and 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS are given in Fig. 7. The phase change temperature and the latent heat of 3.0 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS are 31.4 ℃ and 262.1 J/g, respectively (Fig. 7(a)). Fig. 7(b) shows that the melting temperature of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS is 31.6 ℃ and its latent heat is 256.9 J/g.
As shown in Fig. 3, the latent heat of pure EHS is 280.1 J/g. Clearly, the latent heat of 3.0 wt% and 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS decreases by 6.43% and 8.28%, respectively, compared with that of pure EHS. Notably, this result is consistent with the following equation:
ΔH = ΔH *(1−Φ − Φ − Φ )Al MS boraxM PCM α− O2 3 (1)
where ΔHM represents the calculated latent heat of modified EHS; ΔHPCM represents the latent heat of pure EHS; Φ Al Oα− 2 3，ΦMS and Φborax represent the mass fraction of nano-α-Al2O3, MS and borax, respectively; Φ Φ=MS Al O
2 3 α− 2 3.
As listed in Table 6, the calculated latent heat by the equation is close to the experimental value obtained from DSC, and the relative errors between them are only 0.46% and 0.23% for 3.0 wt% and 4.5 wt % nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS, respectively. It can be seen from the equation that the latent heat of modified EHS decreases with the increases of the mass fractions of the additives including nano-α-Al2O3, MS and borax. The latent heat of modified EHS will not change sharply when the content of nano-α-Al2O3 changes within a very small range such as 1.5 wt%. Additionally, this equation may be valuable for the prediction of latent heat of modified EHS within the certain range of the additive content, which will be further refined and enhanced by the future research.

sections.heading: 3.4. Thermal conductivity analysis
sections.text:
Thermal conductivity, which determines heat charging and dis-
charging rates, is an important parameter in PCMs for thermal energy storage. Fig. 8 shows the thermal conductivities of the modified EHS with nano-α-Al2O3 mass fraction of 0%, 3.0% and 4.5%. The results indicate that the thermal conductivities significantly increase with mass concentrations of nano-α-Al2O3. From Fig. 8a, in liquid state, the thermal conductivities of 3.0 wt% and 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS are, respectively, 10.3% and 21.7% higher than that of control EHS. The thermal conductivity improvement of the corresponding samples in solid state is 26.8% and 61.3%, respectively, as compared to pure EHS (Fig. 8b), and the highest enhancement is up to 61.3%.
Most noteworthy, as the content of nano-α-Al2O3 increases by only an extra 1.5 wt% (from 3.0 to 4.5 wt%), half of the first 3.0 wt% nanoα-Al2O3 content, the thermal conductivities in liquid and solid state are further increased by 11.4% and 34.5%, respectively, which are 1.11 and 1.29 times as that of modified EHS with the 3.0 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 content. This phenomenon can be explained by thermal percolation behavior [35,36]. The heat transfer network built by 3.0 wt% nano-αAl2O3 particles is imperfect in the modified EHS matrix, in which the number of α-Al2O3 nanoparticles contacting with each other is comparably less, resulting in a relatively modest improvement in the thermal conductivity. However, as the content of nano-α-Al2O3 particles comes up to 4.5 wt%, the dosage of thermal conducting fillers breaks the thermal percolation threshold. As a result, more nano-αAl2O3 particles connect with each other and form a denser heat transfer network with a stronger interaction force between nanoparticles, leading to the rapid development of thermal conductivity.
Finally, on the basis of the above analyses, the 4.5 wt% nano-αAl2O3 modified EHS (sample N8) is entitled as the optimized composition to modify EHS as indicated by its high thermal conductivity well over that of 3.0 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS.
3.5. Thermal and chemical stability of modified EHS
The major criterion that has limited extensive use of latent heat storage materials is the service life of PCMs in which their properties have not any degradation after a certain number of thermal cycles [34]. The thermal stability of a PCM needs to be verified through thermal cycle testing to ensure a long service life [37].
The accelerated thermal cycle test containing 200 melting-freezing cycles was carried out for the 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS. The cooling curves and DSC melting curves of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS after 1, 100 and 200 cycles are shown in Figs. 9 and 10, respectively. From Fig. 9, the supercooling degrees of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS after 100 and 200 thermal cycles are, respectively, 1.7 and 1.5 ℃, which are only ± 0.1 ℃ away from that of first melting. In Fig. 10, the phase change temperature is 31.5 ℃ and the latent heat is 254.2 J/g after 200 thermal cycles. Compared with
that at 1 and 100 thermal cycles, the phase change temperature almost keeps constant and latent heat only drops by 1.05% and 0.24%, respectively. Based on these results, it is concluded that the 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS has an excellent thermal stability.
The FTIR spectra of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS after 1, 100 and 200 cycles are depicted in Fig. 11. It is clearly seen that the FTIR spectra after 100 and 200 thermal cycles are almost identical to that after the first cycle, which indicates that the chemical structure of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS is stable without being influenced
by thermal cycling. Thus, it is concluded that 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS has a better chemical stability.

sections.heading: 3.6. Microstructure analysis
sections.text:
The optical micrographs of pure and 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS are presented in Fig. 12. Fig. 12a reveals that pure EHS is composed of lots of bulky crystal particles with the particle size of approximately 0.5–1.5 µm. Compared with pure EHS, the 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS has a smooth, fine and uniform crystalline structure, and at the same magnification no coarse grains are observed in Fig. 12b. The refinement of the morphology may be explained as follows: nano-α-Al2O3 particles in EHS matrix, which serve as the main cites for EHS nucleating, provide numerous nucleation cores as scaffolds for attachment and growth of EHS crystals. Increasing crystal nucleus enhances the formation of small crystal grains, which are more likely to evenly distribute in matrix than the grains in larger sizes, as similar as the occurrence in the metals, alloys and polymers [38–40].
Fig. 13 shows SEM photographs and EDS analysis of 4.5 wt% nanoα-Al2O3 modified EHS. Fig. 13a indicates that raw nano-α-Al2O3 particles are basically granular and the size of particles ranges between 70 and 200 nm. There are some bigger aggregates, which could be formed by gathering of small particles. As can be seen from Fig. 13b, the fine granules closely packed on the surface of region A are crystalline grains of EHS. Region B is nano-α-Al2O3 particles dispersed in matrix of EHS, and the tiny granules clinging to nano-α-Al2O3 particles are also grains of EHS. Fig. 13c shows the EDS micro-area
composition of the structure enclosed by red box in Fig. 13b, the mass fraction of Al element reaches 14.37%, indicating that there are nanoα-Al2O3 particles embedding inside the structure. Namely, it is a structure that is formed by nano-α-Al2O3 nanoparticles clad with grains of EHS. From the Al element area profile (lower right corner of Fig. 13b) in which red dots scattered evenly represent Al element, nano-α-Al2O3 particles are dispersed or embedded into the matrix of EHS uniformly based on the fact that X-ray exciting depth can reach under the surface layer 0.5–5 µm. Therefore, it is concluded that the microstructure of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS composite
consists mostly of EHS grains attached to α-Al2O3 nanoparticles which serve as nucleation cores. This result confirms the interpretation for Fig. 12.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, EHS prepared by using 25 wt% Na2SO4·10H2O and 75 wt% Na2HPO4·12H2O had a melting temperature of 31.2 ℃ and latent heat of 280.1 J/g. The phase separation of EHS was eliminated, but the supercooling degree is still up to 7.8 ℃. In the process of further
improving performances of EHS, the following results were obtained:
(1) Nano-α-Al2O3 could be used as main nucleating agents to prevent supercooling of EHS, and it is essential that borax served as auxiliary nucleating agents. The supercooling degree of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS was decreased from 7.8 ℃ to 1.6 ℃ and its melting temperature and latent heat of fusion were 31.6 ℃ and 256.9 J/g, respectively. (2) Nano-α-Al2O3 to EHS had little influence on phase change behavior. When the mixing proportion of nano-α-Al2O3 increased from 3.0 to 4.5 wt%, there was a little decrease in latent heat of modified EHS. (3) Nano-α-Al2O3 could distinctly increase the thermal conductivity of EHS by 21.7% and 61.3% in liquid and solid state, respectively, for nano-α-Al2O3 loading of 4.5 wt%. (4) OM and SEM results revealed the mechanism of nucleation that αAl2O3 nanoparticles dispersed uniformly in EHS matrix and acted as nucleation cores on which EHS crystals could easily attach and grow, resulting in a significant reduction in the supercooling degree of EHS. (5) DSC and FT-IR results proved the 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS had an excellent thermal and chemical stability after 200 melting-freezing cycles, indicating that it is a promising candidate for thermal energy storage applications at heating solar greenhouses and active solar heating systems in buildings.

The major criterion that has limited extensive use of latent heat storage materials is the service life of PCMs in which their properties have not any degradation after a certain number of thermal cycles [34].

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, a novel Na2SO4·10H2O-Na2HPO4·12H2O eutectic hydrated salt (EHS) with melting temperature of 31.2 °C/no phase separation was firstly prepared for thermal energy storage applications at heating solar greenhouses and active solar heating systems in buildings. In order to inhibit supercooling and enhance thermal conductivity of EHS, nano-α-Al2O3 at different weight proportions was loaded into EHS. The multi-factors orthogonal test method has been employed to evaluate the nucleation effects of nano-α-Al2O3. Besides, various characterization techniques such as DSC, OM, SEM and FT-IR were adopted to investigate the thermal properties, microstructure and chemical stability. The results showed that nano-α-Al2O3 was a highly effective nucleating agent and excellent thermal conductive filler. The supercooling degree was reduced from 7.8 °C to 1.6 °C and the thermal conductivities were improved by up to 61.3% when adding 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 and 1.0 wt% borax. Moreover, the latent heat of 4.5 wt% nano-α-Al2O3 modified EHS decreased by only about 8% and its melting point maintained constant as that of pure EHS. In addition, the modified EHS had good thermal and chemical stability after 200 thermal cycles.
